Description: Stela carved in limestone, inscribed with 35 lines in hieroglyphic script. Top of stela with scene in relief, very crudely executed, framed to left and right by was sceptre and above by winged sun; scene depicting the triad of Naukratis, the pharaoh Ptolemy V and his wife Cleopatra I; pharaoh represented to left in a striding pose, brandishing a macehead; complete, chipped.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Egyptian Museum, Cairo. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The stela presents a similar composition as the so-called ‘Damanhur stela’, another stela of Ptolemy V (CG 22188 / JE 22264), which J. Yoyotte thought to be a pendant of this one (Yoyotte 1993-94, 690-692). The deities depicted however are Amun-Ra, Great God, Lord of the Sky, and Mut and Khonsu, the Holy triad revered in Naukratis. The stela recapitulates the decrees of 186 and 184 BC, which are known by copies in Philae. Yoyotte, J. 1993/94, ‘Les contacts entre Égyptiens et Grecs, viie-iie siècles avant J.-C. : Naucratis, ville égyptienne, (1992–1993, 1993–1994)’, Annuaire du Collège de France, 679–92.
Bibliographic references: Yoyotte 1993-1994 / Les contacts entre Égyptiens et Grecs, viie-iie siècles avant J.-C. : Naucratis, ville égyptienne, (1992–1993, 1993–1994) (p. 690-692)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (BB.04)
Associated names: Named in inscription: Ptolemy V Epiphanes
